Name: Time Reborn: From the Crisis in Physics to the Future of the Universe

ReviewList.Text: I am a big fan on Lee Smolin. He’s a courageous theoretical physicist who is not afraid to be a pioneer of new ideas and new approaches to physics. I have enjoyed all his books with my favorite being his first “Life of the Cosmos”. In this book, Dr. Smolin argues that time is real and not an illusion as some believe the case may be due to relativity. One of Dr. Smolin’s strongest arguments for the reality of time is that the universe and the world clearly show evidence that evolution has taken place which can only occur if time is real. He believes the universe shows signs of evolution and that black holes are ultimately the seeds to new universes and universes have evolved, through cosmic natural selection, to produce many black holes. He makes some profound statements: “There are aspects of the real universe that will never be representable in mathematics… One of them is that in the real world it is always some particular moment”. He makes some statements that seem to go beyond what we can really be sure about: “The universe has no relation to anything outside it”. Overall, I think this book is a worthwhile read. The only problem I had was that some of the discussions were difficult to tie into the main topic. Keep an open mind when reading this. You will learn a lot about the history of the concept of time from the point of view of theoretical physics.

If you are into the quantum, cosmology, etc. then you probably know Lee Smolin already. His latest book is thought provoking, even if a little verbose. One of the nice things about mathematics is that it is not verbose. Some of these physics/maths writers would do well to take a leaf from mathematics' book.

Dr. Smolin lays out a fascinating case for what he labels "temporal naturalism," a fundamental philosophy that appears to be at odds with what most students are taught as a basic tenet of special relativity: the relativity of sumultaneity, which underpins the concept of spacetime and leads to a no-present "block universe" view. The author does a masterful job of presenting complex theoretical arguments in simple, clear terms that make for a highly readable and instructive journey through the mysteries and controversies of contemporary physics. His long personal quest to make sense of apparently paradoxical concepts comes through in the writing, which veers between scientific skepticism and assertions that at times seem passionately strident. As a layperson, I often experienced frustration with arguments that seemed to conflate our intuitive sense of the passage of time with objective universal theoretical constructs, especially in discussions of local versus global phenomena, which often seemed to beg more questions than they resolved. He saves some crucial issues of subjectivity and qualia for the epilogue, and I was left questioning whether the blank-and-white question of time as presented was truly fundamental or tangled in semantic ambiguities and questions beyond the current reach of empirical science. Yet, I would call this a must-read for anyone interested in the philosophy of science and I have tremendous admiration for the brilliance of its author, and appreciation for his devotion to interpreting theoretical physics for an audience of inquisitive amateur philosophers like me.

Many people don't realize that modern science offers a confused view of the nature of time.  Many prominent contemporary physicists view time as being a persistent illusion; others, like Smolin, think that time is the essence of reality: we live within time.  I'll go with Smolin, since his view is consistent with my own research dealing with organized complexity and emergent behavior in microbial systems.
Assuming a general knowledge of physics and a basic familiarity of cosmology from the part of the reader, it is a very good read.
I liked this even better than the Farewell to REality which is similar in scope. Again best in small, digestible readings

Dr. Smolin proposes some theories to revive the concept of time. To most of us may seem obvious that time is real, but actually, according to the current physics viewpoint and Dr. Smolin explanation, time doesn't exist. Today mainstream physicists believe we live in a Universe completely defined in a four dimensional block that goes from Big Bang to the end of time, which in fact, makes time an illusion, as well as many other things, such as free will and choice. Time Reborn argues that time is absolutely real and proposes some theories or ideas as to how handle this in physics. Time is real, but space is not. This is hard to digest and I do hope some other even better theory can explain our reality, which everyday seems to get more and more complex and surreal. We really need now another Einstein!

Terrific, and as usual with Smolin, contrary to the group-think that afflicts modern physics. Finally, someone who goes beyond the mumbo-jumbo pseudo-mysticism that you read with all of the physicists that buy into the "timeless" state of the universe. Time is real—the most real thing there is.

The author is intrigued by some very deep questions of science and philosophy. He also is well versed on the current state of particle theory and cosmology. I feel I followed his arguments well enough I wondered how well the non-expert will.

At last someone with both credentials and courage really saying something new and profound, instead of parroting the same old stale paradigms!  This book is for anyone interested in physics, cosmology or ultimate reality.

A very excellent and comprehensive review of where cosmology and physics stands now and where it needs to go next to become a real science.  I would highly recommend this book to all my high school physics students.
This is somewhat off the beaten physics track: it presents a different view of space and time absolutes. And it makes testable predictions. Interesting and challenging.
Presents integrated frameworks of thought that enable one to think of the world and science in entirely new ways, yet easy-to-read.

Time Reborn is OK, but the extensions to societal generalisms were a bit annoying.  Smolin could have tried to tie the technical side down a bit more; such as why time cancels out of cosmology.  His explanation of his idea of the adjacentcy of the grains of space seems pretty weak.  ...and a few more simple equations could help.  Of course, multidimensionality is difficult, but I am reminded of Feynman's line that if you can't explain it, you probably don't know it.

I was very disappointed in this book. It was good for stimulating my thinking and pointing me to some useful references, but came across to me as incoherent.  I never quite understood where he was going and he never seemed to get there.

The first half of the book is very interesting a Smolin outlines the development of the laws of physics. I particularly liked the way he correlated controlled experiments and closed systems, that is the way that hypotheses become theories and then laws. Later in the book, he launches into theories relating to the whole universe even the multiverse. At this stage he prefers Leibniz sufficient reason over the idea that every theory in physics should be testable. Rather obviously theories about the whole universe, let alone the multiverse, derived by an observer from a small planet in a small galaxy are hardly testable. He then concludes that time is real, there is an arrow of time, there is cause and effect but not before Smolin appears to launch into 21st century scholasticism. By the end of the book, I felt that the last few chapters were written with his tongue in his cheek. It is an entertaining read although I would prefer a book that discusses in lay terms the contradictions in modern physics.

It is a thoughtful, honest, and well articulated discussion of some of the problems being encountered in Physics and gives a supported rational for the significance of our understanding the meaning and importance of time.  There is a high corespondence in his understanding of time and that of process philosophers (Whitehead in particular).  I am surprised he has not explored this connection, or if he has why there is no discussion.  While valuing Leibnitz, most process philosophers have moved to a more nuanced understanding of time while still building on its significance.  Having said that there is still much in this book and I highly recommend it to all those interested in process thought.

This was an interesting book, but I feel like it makes it quite clear why concepts in physics the author doesn't endorse - namely string theory - are more popular with the public than the ideas expressed here: the ideas presented are frequently impenetrable and the writing seems to jump from topic to topic without making it very clear what is meant. I mean, it would probably help if I understood physics better, but that's precisely what I'm saying: it's been easier for me to at least feel like I am understanding what authors like Brian Greene and Michio Kaku are saying when they discuss their ideas about physics than it was for me to understand Lee Smolin. Still, I'm glad I read this book.

Time Reborn is an attempt by the author to provide (at a layperson level) a potential solution to the problems he outlined in his former book called "The Trouble With Physics". I think Time Reborn is well worth reading but I got less out of it than the other book he wrote that I mentioned previously. I did however, find some of this book quite fascinating. The author attempts to insert time into physics while at the same time acknowledging that mathematical equations are essentially timeless, and that to place time into physics would be problematic because of this. The author spends a lot of time going over issues such as this; issues that straddle both science and philosophy. He covers aspects of the work of the mathematician/philosopher Leibniz, for example, a part of the book I found quite fascinating. I have no idea whether he is on to something with this book, I don't have the expertise to know. However, if you have already read "The Trouble with Physics" or you are in the mood for some a philosophical/scientific/mathematical discussion of a potential solution to the problems in physics that exist today, I recommend reading this book.

Smolin's latest popular book summarizes his work in physics since he abandoned String Theory. The basic premise is that time is real, not an abstraction as implied by the Einstein Equations. I tend to agree, so that made this book much more interesting to me. Not an easy read, but well worth it.

It took perseverance to read as I am not a student of physics. I can't speak with authority to the science but I am cheered by the philosophy. Having a cosmology that's conceivably verifiable is far more promising than the vagueness of string theory and multiverses. Glad I pushed through this.
Lee Smolin is a very original thinker. He offers some new and original ideas about physics that encourage new research. I love his books.

On the positive side, Smolin gives a good overview of contemporary views on time and the development of modern cosmology. On the negative side I am not sure I understood his own theoretical framework which seems to hinge on a kind of hidden variables interpretation of quantum mechanics that was espoused by Einstein, Bohm and others. I am not a theoretical physicist so I can't really judge the validity of his approach, but unlike some other recent popular books on physics this book left me a little nonplussed. It's still quite good for a historical overview though. Also recommended is Sean Carroll's book, also about time but easier to understand.
If you want to know where physics is going now that it's reached the dead end of time-is-not-real, read this. A bonus is that Smolin writes beautifully.

Lee Smolin does not have all the answers.  What he does have is a very curious mind that is seeking answers, testable ones.  Dr. Smolin does a very good job of explaining the present crisis in physics, the increasing disconnect between researchers being trained today and why there needs to be a new paradigm that will include time in the equations.  Some researchers seek Natures‘ truths, others seek to find more devices, tools and toys for humanity.  There will be room for both but the first is science the second, technology. The cart should remain behind the horse and in this case, give the horse some more leeway, let‘s be curious once again, let‘s try something new, it is high time.

After trying to read this book, I became so disturbed at its implications that I began jumping ahead a bit, trying to find something which did not offend what I understand to be the nature of the universe, and I never found it.  This was written by a man who has a personal agenda against certain current popular theories in physics and a chip on his shoulder when it comes to mathematics.  He describes mathematicians and physicists of certain sensibilities to be "searching for the eternal" when this idea quite flies in the face of everything which science and mathematics stand for.  He still never described Time to my satisfaction or really explained how it existed at the start of history, and uses a lot of vague terms such as the fact that the internet has essentially given us an extra "spatial" dimension or that "internet-like" space sprung out of Time.  Pass this one over.
Very interesting contribution to the "time is an illusion/time is real" debate.  Enjoyable read!
Extremely well written. And a fascinating look at "science" today. Don't miss this one.

This is a great book on the nature of time with a focus on showing that since relativity became the main paradigm - and does because it works well for many things and solves many problems - it leaves open the problem of time that also must be solved. But rather than work within the paradigm of relativity that means time is not real but instead a matter of interpretation and systems used to measure it, there must instead be a new paradigm that respects time as real as well. The arguments are clear and the explanations beautiful (though the diagrams look deliberately homemade and make you feel like you are in class with Lee while he draws on the board). This is an excellent book and should be the next major introduction to time that people read.
Good primer about nature of time.

This good author should have waited until he really had something new to say before releasing this book. And this, so shortly after his last excellent critique of today's physics. He falls prey to what he was denouncing then, dragging the reader in a meander of  fuzzy thoughts about time that really don't connect to the practical and the sensible in us. His intellectual cul-de-sac made a lot of reader including myself drop out of this depressing little trip that really tells nothing of interest. He probably needed the money to send his child to college and I forgive him. But his book will not have the impact on the science of physics comparable to an asteroid hitting the earth. In my humble opinion, it is more like a micro-meteorite impacting  a high-floating cloud when no one is looking.

Much less good than L. Smolin's other book(s) in my opinion. About 1/3 of the way through, the author keeps telling you that a new model for time is needed, wothout ever telling you what itis. The distinctions between 'reality' and timeless mathematical formulations seem artificial to me, and/or not well explained. A book written in haste,perhaps?

If this is an attempt to propound a theory of cosmology addressed to a not overly bright layman, it is a failure. The book is filled with meaningless definitions of arcane terms. The author's vigorous attempt  to explain to the reader what his quarrel  with accepted theory is all about lacks clarity and concision. Maybe he is right that an objective time lies at the core of our universe but reading this book made it drag on interminably.

Fascinating book,enjoy reading this book. The author deals with the many theories surrounding the concept of time. I  now have a better understanding of the limitations of these theories an science as a whole. I heard the author on a podcast which peaked my interest in his book; was everything that I expected, great book a must read if you like science!

Well written book, understandable by the layman, by one of the leading theoretical physicists of our time. This is a great book to make you think about the place of time in our understanding of the universe.  He does not shrink from challenging the thinking that has dominated physics for the past 90 years.

Only half through the book but Smolin proposes ideas that challenge much accepted wisdom about the universe, tying together disparate areas. He is especially good at cutting to the core of complex topics such as relativity and quantum theory, reducing them to their essence.

This book got more and more tedious the further I read into it. In the end I gave up about 2/3 rd's of the way through and now a few weeks later have forgotten most of what I read. Nowhere near as good as some of Mr Smolin's earlier books (which is why I purchased this in the first place). It seemed to have been slapped together in a hurry and could have done with some major editing plus some better diagrams (which were pretty amateurish).
Lee Smolin may not have the next great theory of physics but he raises several very important questions regarding current theoretical Physics.

I'm afraid I found this rather frustrating. The content is a mixture of material which is quite easy to understand (and most of which I already knew), interspersed with very high-powered discussions which seemed to require a profound prior knowledge of cosmological theory to understand. Part of the problem may be the absence of equations (it doesn't even include E=mc^2): there are many places where a lot of verbiage can be replaced and often made clearer by an equation or two. Somehow the author seemed to feel that readers would be put off by equations but not put off by sentences like "These include the approaches called causal set theory, matrix models of string theory, and dynamical triangulations." Whew! In fairness, the author does suggest that the reader simply skip things he doesn't understand, and I did find my bearing a few pages later, but the problem I had with the book was that I already knew the things that I could understand, and I was utterly baffled by the rest of it.

I am extremely fascinated by Dr Smolin's theories and work on quantum gravity.  However, this book does not have the same zest and clarity that you find in other lay science books such as those by Brian Greene.  I would read it if like me you enjoy this topic but be forewarned that it will be a tough slog.

A fine example of what happens when foundational questions arise that call the very existence of the science into question.  The result is empirically informed speculation of the highest order--interesting first to last.
New thoughts about a human inspired problem. Reality vs. imagination. Time is real, the only constant is change as Heraclitus stated long ago.
I like the book, although, I was a little disappointed because I wanted time to be an illusion, something just created in our minds! :D
Author is willing to present new ideas that run somewhat counter to convention.  Well thought out and documented in readable form.
This is an amazing work of literature that I highly recommended to anyone interested in quantum theory and time theories.
Recipient was very pleased with this book.  He had it on his want list for a long time.  Thank you

Lee Smolin is a good physicist, but in this book, he's gotten distracted by foolish philosophy. He may have valid physical intuition that leads him to think of time as fundamental. But in this book, his arguments come off as naive appeals to the subjective phenomena of the passage of time, which is divorced from scientific models. I guess that's sort of his point, but he hasn't offered any new way to do science. He's just complained that science can't account for his subjective view of time. He seems to have gotten roped up by qualia and other such mystical nonsense. Its sad.
I liked the new perspective - and the fact that there were now math equations.

I am not completely convinced that this collection of words reflects a real alternative, but in years of reading "popular physics" this is one of the most unique and illuminating perspectives I have encountered.
I got hooked on the Trouble With Physics. Like his other books, this book on time is easy to read and very thought provoking.
Excellent
It was a reasonbly good book.  To get the most out of the book I would probably have to reread it
This was definitely the most mind-blowing book I've come across! The drawings in the book were also cute. It is definitely an awesome physics book
Trying too hard to convince others toward his viewpoint angle.  However probably the most objective theoretical physicist out there right now.
DR SMOLIN  is a very sharp scientist and has courage and tenacity.  He is close to an Einstein but should stop sniping at Albert.

I live in Australia and was so impressed by this Kindle edition that I tried to gift it to a friend  a Kindle user who lives in UK via Amazon. I was amazed and dismayed when he told me that for some reason which is not clear Amazon had told him that this Kindle edition was not available in UK and instead of contacting me and refunding my gift offered him some unspecified replacement . Since the  book deals with time maybe they are going to send him a Kindle edition of  The Time Sleeping Beauty Awoke  or maybe Time And Rip Van Winkle. I rate Lee Smolin's work highly but I rate Amazon's performance in this matter at 00.00
Great product. Fast delivery.
This is written in "everyman" language but has concepts not for the man on the street.  For me, the best part was the epilogue which showed more about the author.
Well written, not just for those with a deep understanding of the question of time.  I feel better informed about the world in general.
This scientist refuses to march in lock-step and is accomplishing much. That is so needed. A breath of fresh air.
Nothing special. It's a boring book.

Read the book and thought for sure I would eventually start reading about Hegel, for whom, as argued by Kojève, the Concept=Time. Indeed, Kojève saw that for Hegel "truth is time". Smolin (and his compatriot, Unger) may have missed a good ally for their arguments. Perhaps in their forthcoming collaboration, The Singular Universe and the Reality of Time . . . I hope.
Logically convoluted story that is almost impossible to follow. Pus i don't agree with his premise that time is a fundamental value. Well, not the kind he says it is anyway.
It was not a regular CD that I could play on my cd player.  It seems to be in MP3 format which I can't use.
Again, they returned this item without my permission and then refunded only a partial payment.  What is up with that! AAA
